𝗜𝗻 𝗺𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝗮𝗹 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗼𝗹𝗼𝗴𝘆, 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗳 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗻𝗲𝘄. Sustainability can mean starting from scratch—but more often, it’s about analyzing and reimagining what we already have.

Take for example, our MRI systems where an upgraded cold head can mean using far less helium or a refurbished scanner can be carefully restored to serve patients for years to come. Another example is our lab diagnostic systems. These workhorses often run nonstop in busy hospital labs and, after years of heavy use, can be rigorously restored with the latest hardware and software to perform like new.

These quieter forms of innovation are powerful. Not only do they extend the life of critical technology, they also reduce waste and preserve precious resources. It’s progress—not by replacement, but by renewal.

Equally inspiring is the craftsmanship behind it: Engineers who design smarter ways to trap and reuse helium. Teams who recalibrate systems with precision and care. Their work isn’t always seen, but the impact is felt in every scan delivered without delay and in every patient diagnosis made possible.

At, we believe sustainability starts with design, but lives in the details. That sometimes, a system’s “end of life” is really just the start of a better one.

That’s why I’m delighted to share that we’ve signed a new research agreement with(GSD), a long-standing partner and Italy’s largest healthcare provider. Our primary goal: to establish advanced imaging technologies, such as photon-counting CT, as an integral part of personalized medicine.

Together with GSD’sin Milan, we will develop post-processing software for the automated analysis of photon-counting CT images, with a special focus on lung and cardiovascular imaging. This agreement not only strengthens our relationship and sets the stage for meaningful progress in healthcare delivery — it also completes a major milestone. At Siemens Healthineers, it’s not always about uncovering the unknown. Often, it’s about making what we already see more precise—and more accessible to those who need it most.

Take Cinematic Reality, portrayed in one of the background images on my profile. It marks a shift from flat, grayscale slices to vivid 3D visualizations where anatomy takes on depth, texture, and life-like detail. These immersive, interactive holograms are created directly from real patient data and allow clinicians to explore the human body in entirely new ways.

They can rotate a heart in virtual space, trace the nervous system, or examine a tumor from every angle. It’s not just visually stunning; it’s clinically valuable and offers a lot of potential: Surgeons can plan more precisely. Students can learn more intuitively. Patients can receive care that’s more personalized, more informed. I find this so inspiring because when we see with greater clarity, we can care with greater confidence.

Sometimes the most beautiful breakthroughs aren’t just what we see, but how we see.

What an honor to be in Cleveland, Ohio, celebrating 40 years of partnership with Case Western Reserve University, a collaboration that began just two years after MRI technology became available. 

It’s great reconnecting with renowned experts and colleagues to reflect on how far we’ve come since installing our first clinical system there. When we first started working together, many of the applications we rely on today were still on the horizon. Scans were slow, the experience for patients was often uncomfortable, and image quality was a far cry from what we expect now.

Together, we were motivated by the possibilities to shape this field and so, we started pushing boundaries early on. For example, our work on real-time MRI in the 80s helped lay the groundwork for what we now know as minimally invasive, image-guided procedures. These helped make interventions safer and patient recovery times shorter. Then, thanks to various breakthroughs in the following decades, 3D imaging became reality, scans got faster and more precise, and images became clearer and more detailed.

Because of contributions from partnerships like ours, MRI turned into what we know today: a quicker, more comfortable experience for patients, and a powerful and versatile tool for providers to screen, diagnose, and treat with confidence. It’s been an exciting journey of transforming 𝐛𝐨𝐥𝐝 ideas into solutions used around the world. In many ways, we’re just getting started. We’re already exploring what’s next in precision imaging, AI-driven workflows, and scaling innovations across entire fleets of scanners.

A heartfelt congratulations to the team of experts at Case Western andwho have made these 40 years so meaningful. Your camaraderie, curiosity, and brilliance are behind every breakthrough and the reasons this partnership continues to move forward and deliver real impact for patients and communities.

Thank you,,,,,,,,,,,... your teams, and so many more!

Some innovations look like high-tech marvels. Others are shaped by hand—in fire, with skill passed down through generations.

X-ray technology has advanced in leaps: faster scans, sharper images, greater reliability. But at the heart of every X-ray tube lies a centuries-old craft that still matters today: glassblowing.

In Rudolstadt, Germany, our artisans form the delicate glass components for X-ray tubes by hand. Each piece must withstand extreme heat and pressure, while meeting incredible precision standards. There’s no automation for this level of craftsmanship—just expertise, care, and consistency.

Why does it matter? Because the reliability of these components helps bring diagnostic care to more people, in more places—from hospitals to mobile clinics in remote regions. It’s a reminder that even the most advanced technology depends on people. On craft. On detail.

This is what I love about our work: the intersection of deep tradition and modern impact.

Not all our breakthroughs in medical technology look like a big machine. Sometimes it’s a small vial—filled with a few teaspoons of blood—that carries the potential to change a life.

Take multiple sclerosis (MS), a disease that affects nearly 3 million people worldwide. For many, the wait for symptoms to appear, or for imaging to confirm what they already feel, can be full of uncertainty. Now a simple blood test can deliver key insights and help ensure patients get the right care at the right time. I find this quiet breakthrough so powerful.

The test targets neurofilament light chain (NfL), a blood-based biomarker now detectable with a diagnostic test. This is the first CE-marked* biomarker for MS. When used together with other clinical, imaging, and laboratory findings, NfL can help predict the risk of MS disease activity in an individual patient with RMS. These earlier insights help clinicians personalize treatment earlier and give the patient something often missing: clarity.

It’s not dramatic on the outside, but the impact is very real. This is the kind of innovation I believe deserves more attention—the kind that puts meaningful change in a small vial.

Much of what fuels innovation in healthcare stays behind the scenes (or behind the lab). It’s not always the news of the moment, but it’s the foundation of who we are and what I find fascinating and worth sharing. I’m always astonished by how far we’ve come as a team, and excited by the pace at which we’re changing what will be possible tomorrow. So why not shine a light on some of the overlooked details—or, better yet, the quiet breakthroughs that make all the difference?

Each background picture on my profile has its own story to tell. Yes, as a physicist and a Healthineer, I may be a bit biased. But I think many would agree: there’s a lot of art in science. And the details are often extraordinary.

Take photon-counting CT, for example. To pioneer breakthroughs like this, we now grow crystals—cadmium telluride, to be exact—over 12 intense weeks. In nature, the same process would take millions of years. The purest cadmium telluride crystal is the starting point for a quantum leap in computed tomography technology. Years of research, development, and production have led to the creation of pure crystals with electrical properties that have revolutionized CT detector technology.

Yes, it’s technical. But the impact is very human.

Every touchpoint matters. Because these carefully grown crystals help deliver sharper insights, earlier answers, and better outcomes for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

This is just one glimpse behind the curtain. What do you think about this one? I’ll be sharing what catches my attention from each background soon!

This is good news for patients and physicians everywhere in the world, especially in underserved regions: The World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization, approved a resolution to strengthen medical imaging capacity. 🩻🚀

In a nutshell: This resolution addresses the issue of global equity in access to imaging, recognizing that medical imaging is vital for the diagnosis and treatment of numerous diseases, injuries and other health conditions. Thus, it urges the WHO member states "to promote appropriate and continued access to quality, safe, affordable and cost-effective medical imaging capacity, by implementing appropriate policies, strategies, programmes, norms and standards".

While the decisions of the World Health Assembly are not legally binding, they carry significant political and strategic influence. We atwelcome this decision wholeheartedly and with great confidence in its added value for patients. We stand ready to support our customers and partners in its implementation. Its essence precisely captures the purpose of our company that drives us every day: We pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare – for everyone, everywhere, sustainably.

𝗙𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗮𝗱𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗶𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗯𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸𝘁𝗵𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘀. Today we celebrate 50 years of Computed Tomography at Siemens Healthineers. For me personally, it has been an absolute privilege to experience more than half of that journey so far, seeing how our progress and pioneering role in CT exemplify what our company stands for.

I joined the CT team as a product manager 26 years ago, right after we launched our newest innovation at the time: multislice CT technology with the SOMATOM Volume Zoom. Multislice took CT to another level, starting to transform the cross-sectional imaging (essentially, a 2D paradigm) into producing an "isotropic 3D copy" of the patient. A universe of new clinical applications opened up: from metastasis screening to vascular imaging to the first CT images of the coronaries. And viewing slices like on a film sheet, turned into browsing in the "3D copy" of the patient with the first post-processing applications.

Making these breakthroughs available for everyone everywhere quickly became our target and within just one decade, all of our CT scanners, even in the entry level, had multislice technology inside.

Among the things our CT team is exemplary for all Healthineers: the team constantly thinks ahead, never resting on their laurels. Even amid the "Slice Wars" in the early 2000s, they were already at work on the revolutionary dual-source CT technology while simultaneously starting the photon-counting project and becoming the frontrunner in AI applications. Their enduring mindset has driven incredible advances in cardiovascular imaging and in diagnosing cancer, stroke, and lung disease. CT has become so widely used across many cases that it’s now an essential tool in clinical settings like the emergency room and radiotherapy planning – the latter being elementary in our successful combination with.

As for photon-counting CT… We – and more importantly, many of our customers – are convinced it’s set to become the standard for CT in the future. It has the potential to be a true catalyst in preventive healthcare, helping to detect diseases earlier and creating an almost digital twin of the patient. With that level of insight, clinicians can make faster and more personalized decisions on the next step for their patient.

We were the first to introduce the photon-counting CT scanner in 2021. Our focus has since shifted to a bigger question: how can we ensure everyone, everywhere truly benefits from this technology? Just as we were the fastest to make multislice CT accessible to all, our ambition now is to positively impact 1 billion lives over the next decade by bringing photon-counting CT within reach of more communities.

We got to this point because of the dedication, vision, and hard work of
and – as importantly – through the inspiration, collaboration, trust, and scientific brilliance of our partners in clinical research in medical institutions worldwide. Thank you!

Reflecting on my brief but meaningful visit to Poland this week, one thing is clear: the capital city of Warsaw is emerging as a destination for healthcare excellence, particularly for the youngest patients needing specialized care and for providers honing their diagnostics skills.

Atin Warsaw, it was a privilege to meet with the experts making remarkable progress in researching and treating the most complex and challenging pediatric cases. Their commitment to enhancing – and saving – these young lives is truly inspiring, and we are honored that they have long been aGlobal Pediatric Reference Center. CHMI is also an important scientific collaboration partner of ours, with cooperation going beyond the country to the CEECA regional level. Some recent collaboration projects include using brain scans to better understand how multiple sclerosis develops, testing different PET scans to find where seizures begin in children with epilepsy, and finding ways to make MRI scans less stressful for adolescents (and their parents). Thank you, Dr. Marek Migdał, Prof. Elżbieta Jurkiewicz, Prof. Bozenna Dembowska-Baginska, and Dr. Anna Śliwińska for your time and the great exchange between our teams!

While collaboration with our scientific partners fuels innovation, it’s hands-on training and education for technicians and clinicians that bring that innovation to life in everyday healthcare. The experts at the 𝗦𝗶𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘀 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗔𝗰𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗺𝘆 in Warsaw play a key role in this effort, offering specialized master classes, many of them peer-to-peer, across all diagnostic modalities. I was happy to finally set foot in the Academy and personally thank the hard-working team that has trained more than 27,000 radiologists and other healthcare professionals from Poland and abroad over the last nine years.

A big thanks also toand the entire
Poland for your warm welcome and lively dialogues. You are making a difference for your customers and the patients they serve – keep up the terrific work!

Siemens Healthineers has been deeply connected to Poland for a long time – building strong partnerships and collaborating with providers to pioneer breakthroughs for everyone, everywhere, sustainably. Yesterday, I had the honor to meet with, Dr., Prof.and their team atand explore how we can take that progress even further.

As Poland’s leader in the private healthcare sector, Lux Med is big on operational efficiency and improving the patient experience across their 300 clinics and hospitals. They are rethinking how technology drives smarter planning and are putting AI to work to empower their teams—so that the 2.5 million patients that come through their doors each year can get better, faster, and more personalized care.

For example, we are pleased to already support them with AI solutions in radiology. It was fantastic to learn about the positive impact so far, especially how they’ve managed to accelerate MRI scans with the aid of our AI-powered image reconstruction technology – something we’ve been hearing consistently from other adopters. Soon, Lux Med will also integrate our remote scanning capabilities to help improve local access to advanced imaging while addressing the ongoing workforce shortage of technologists.

Thank you again to the entire Lux Med team for your hospitality and motivating discussions. We’re excited to continue working with you.

Zu meinen schönsten Privilegien als CEO von Siemens Healthineers gehört es, mich mit jungen Menschen aus der ganzen Welt über ihre Ziele und Ideen zu unterhalten. Viele von ihnen stehen am Anfang ihrer Karriere und wollen wissen, wie das bei mir damals war. Besonders häufig kommen diese drei Fragen. Vielleicht hilft es ja jemandem, wenn ich sie hier einmal gesammelt beantworte – ohne Anspruch auf Allgemeingültigkeit.

🚀 "Wie war der Start in dein Berufsleben?"

Ich habe nach meiner Promotion in Theoretischer Physik bei Siemens angefangen. Aber es hat etwas gedauert, bis ich dort den richtigen Platz für mich gefunden hatte. Doch mit dem Verständnis für die Zusammenhänge von Medizin, Technik, Wirtschaft und Gesundheit wuchs dann auch die Begeisterung immer mehr. Ich weiß noch sehr genau, wie ich plötzlich morgens ohne Wecker aufgewacht bin, weil ich unbedingt wieder loslegen wollte, weil mich meine Aufgabe und die Menschen dort so fasziniert haben.

🧠 "Wer war – oder ist – dein Vorbild?"

Ich glaube, dass man von jedem Menschen etwas lernen kann. Das ist das Schöne an diversen, internationalen Teams, wo jedes Mitglied einen anderen Hintergrund und andere Erfahrungen mitbringt. Besonders gerne erinnere ich mich aber an Professor Erich Reinhardt, damals Bereichsvorstand für die Medizintechnik bei Siemens. Er hat uns beigebracht, wie man richtig streitet. Das beste Argument zählt, nicht wer es vorbringt. "Wir brauchen eine Streitkultur, keinen Harmonieterror", hat er oft gesagt. Und damit hat er das Unternehmen, das ich jetzt führen darf, bis heute geprägt.

🍽️ "Hast du ein Rezept für beruflichen Erfolg?"

Ich habe kein Rezept, aber vielleicht einen Rat. In der Rückschau sehe ich meinen Weg als eine Verkettung glücklicher Zufälle. Aber diese Zufälle müssen schon auf eine gute Vorbereitung treffen, damit sie auch wirken können. Ich glaube, für junge Menschen ist es wichtig, sich verschiedene Dinge anschauen zu können. So findet man heraus, was einen wirklich begeistert. Das Leben ist zu kurz, um Dinge zu tun, die man nicht liebt. Und dann wird man auch nicht gut darin. Lasst euch also nicht von anderen stressen, wenn ihr mit 18 oder 20 noch keinen großen Plan habt. Aber wartet auch nicht, bis euch auf magische Weise die Motivation überkommt. Fangt etwas an, schnuppert rein – wenn es das Richtige für euch ist, folgen Motivation und Erfolg dann ganz automatisch.

As a Berliner by choice, many of the city's monuments remind me time and again of the brutalities of war and Nazi terror: from the Holocaust Memorial to the destroyed Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church and the site honoring victims of the Nazi euthanasia program. These are depressing places. Not suppressing the crimes and horrors, but remembering them in the midst of our diverse, vibrant, pulsating capital today gives hope: never again!

80 years ago today, the Second World War ended and with it, the Nazi regime. Together with 47 other German companies, we therefore want to pay respects to the victims of this dark chapter in our country’s history. At the same time, we would like to remember the hope that the end of the war brought to Europe and the world. International cohesion, the rule of law, and freedom are achievements that we must protect together.

Our democracy is precious, it thrives on participation, courage and dissent. It also requires effort and many compromises, but in return it gives us peace, security and prosperity – and provides us with the strength to stand up for others who are threatened by war, terror, and persecution today. We stand by our responsibility: not only out of a historical obligation, but out of deep human conviction.

Fifteen years ago, I had the privilege of being a participant in the Baden-Badener Unternehmer Gespräche e.V. (BBUG), preparing for increasingly responsible roles alongside amazing peers from companies across various industries. Today, after more than 10 years as CEO of, I had the honor and pleasure of speaking to those who are now preparing for their own future leadership roles, having been nominated by their companies.

I always greatly enjoy moments like these—they are enriching, offering fresh perspectives and thought-provoking questions. Plus, simply explaining one’s own work helps sharpen one’s own thinking.

Of course, there was a lot to share at the beginning: about non-communicable diseases (cancer, cardiovascular disease, stroke, etc.), which we are dedicated to combating; about access to care for 8 billion people; and about the shortage of healthcare professionals among our customers. We also discussed our IPO, the combination with, the central role of AI in our products, the path to groundbreaking innovations like Photon-Counting CT, and our Value Partnerships with leading customers.

The discussion that followed was lively and engaging, conducted under Chatham House Rules—which is why I summarize the following seven key takeaways:

1️⃣ We should not see healthcare spending as a cost but as an investment in a better life.
2️⃣ The healthcare industry is a vital yet often underestimated part of a country's economic value creation.
3️⃣ Medical technology is an exciting "dialogue discipline" where progress is only possible through deep mutual understanding between medical professionals and engineers. This is fascinating—but also teaches humility.
4️⃣ Our IPO allowed us to create a much more focused company, entirely dedicated to our specific customer base, and to reinvent ourselves. I am deeply grateful for that. And only through the IPO the combination with Varian was possible, for example.
5️⃣ Progress always moves in two directions: Improving what already exists and creating access where it was previously unaffordable.For example, digitalization initially digitizes what was analog, but "digital first" solutions bypass analog altogether, making things possible for the first time. Many medical breakthroughs follow the same principle.
6️⃣ Right now, we talk a lot about managing change in the world. My advice: from time to time, consciously reflect on what does NOT change and what always holds true.
7️⃣ And lastly: Take good care of your own health and your relationships.

Thank you,, for the invitation, and thank you to all the participants for the fantastic discussion!

Seit einigen Jahren ist Berlin meine Wahlheimat – neben einem zweiten Wohnsitz in der wunderschönen Stadt Bamberg nahe dem Erlanger Medical Valley, einem der größten Standorte unserer Firma. An Berlin liebe ich sehr die Diversität, die Lebendigkeit und die Energie – vor allem und insbesondere aber, wie es uns die deutsche Geschichte bewusst macht und sowohl an die grauenvollsten Momente erinnert als auch an den Kampf für die starke Demokratie, die daraus hervorgegangen ist.

Das Denkmal für die ermordeten Juden in der Nähe des Brandenburger Tors und die zerstörte Kaiser-Wilhelm-Gedächtnis-Kirche mahnen, was Rassismus und extremistischer Nationalismus anrichten. Die Reste der Berliner Mauer zeigen, was linker Totalitarismus bedeutet. Die Tunnel an der Bernauer Straße zeugen von der unbändigen Sehnsucht nach Demokratie und Freiheit. Die gläserne Kuppel und die transparenten Gebäude des Regierungsviertels stehen für genau diese Freiheit und Demokratie im endlich geeinten Deutschland.

Wenn ich am nächsten Sonntag wähle, dann mit einem Gefühl der Dankbarkeit für diese Demokratie und der Verantwortung, sie zu schützen und nicht selbstverständlich zu nehmen. Wenn ich am nächsten Sonntag wähle, dann mit der Frage im Kopf, wie ich der Generation meiner Großeltern meine Wahl erklären würde, und wie ich sie der Generation meiner (noch nicht geborenen ;-)) Enkel und Enkelinnen erklären würde. Wenn ich am nächsten Sonntag wähle, dann mit der Freude, dass der Wahlkampf vorbei ist, und dass wir alle zusammen mit einer neuen Bundesregierung, welcher Couleur auch immer, die Stärken unseres Landes und Europas bewahren und ausbauen können.

Die industrielle Gesundheitswirtschaft ist ein Wachstumsmotor für Deutschland und Europa. Das wollen wir auch bleiben. Siemens Healthineers trägt nach Kräften dazu bei: Unser Unternehmen steht nicht nur zum Standort Deutschland, wir prägen ihn. In den vergangenen Jahren haben wir über 650 Millionen Euro in unsere deutschen Standorte investiert – beispielsweise für Zukunftstechnologien der Medizintechnik wie die photonenzählende Computertomographie, in der unser Unternehmen führend ist.

Vor der Bundestagswahl möchte ich die nächste Regierung ermutigen: Stärken Sie die industrielle Gesundheitswirtschaft und rücken Sie sie mehr ins Zentrum von Wirtschafts-, Bildungs- und Innovationspolitik. Wo immer wir hierzu einen Beitrag leisten können, stehen wir bereit. Unsere Branche beschäftigt mehr als eine Million Menschen im Land, trägt fast zehn Prozent der deutschen Exporte und leistet einen bedeutenden Beitrag zur Gesundheitsversorgung weltweit. Als Wissens- und Wissenschaftsbranche passt sie außerdem sehr gut zu Deutschland: Sie ist wenig energieintensiv, kaum konjunkturabhängig und basiert auf Vertrauen.

Die industrielle Gesundheitswirtschaft war heute eines von vielen wichtigen Themen beim "Forum Innovation zur Richtungswahl 2025". Auch andere Vertreter aus Wirtschaft und Wissenschaft haben dabei die Gelegenheit genutzt, ihre jeweiligen Perspektiven mit Mitgliedern des Deutschen Bundestags zu besprechen. Im Gegenzug stellten, Oliver Kaczmarek,unddie Konzepte ihrer Parteien für mehr Innovationsfähigkeit in Deutschland vor.

Ich danke dem, der Nationalen Akademie der Wissenschaften Leopoldina und derfür die Einladung zu dieser spannenden Diskussion.

That concludes our Siemens Healthineers Executive Summit 2024! It was a full day of listening and learning that I was grateful to experience. This year's theme, "Performing today while transforming for tomorrow," has never felt more relevant as healthcare navigates through major changes in technology, social behavior, culture, and the way we deliver care.

Therefore, at the Summit, we concentrated on key topics such as strengthening health equity through scalable systems, transforming healthcare towards patient-centered care, shaping the workforce of tomorrow, and navigating the path to net zero. Our discussions not only addressed these evolving challenges but also deeply resonated with our purpose to pioneer breakthroughs in healthcare for everyone, everywhere, sustainably. Today also showed that no matter our different perspectives and expertise we each bring to the table, we all have a responsibility and contribution to make in caring for the 8 billion people in the world.

I want to express my sincere gratitude to the thought leaders and decision-makers who joined us – your insights enriched our dialogue and your dedication to healthcare is truly inspiring. Special thanks to the whole team, whose tireless efforts behind the scenes made this Summit a great success.

The stage is set for our Siemens Healthineers Executive Summit 2024 tomorrow. For the 6th time, we have gathered over 160 healthcare decision-makers and thought leaders from more than 40 countries to learn from each other. This time, we will focus on how healthcare providers can perform today while transforming for tomorrow.

The challenges we face today and in the future are manifold:

▪ How can we strengthen health equity through scalable systems? We will address the importance of achieving health equity through a comprehensive approach to care that is preventative, accessible, and affordable.
▪ How can we transform healthcare towards patient-centered care? We will explore patients’ decision-making, motivations, diverse needs, and how, where, and why they are engaging with healthcare systems.
▪ How can we shape the workforce of tomorrow? We will discuss how to foster a work culture that values all individuals and attracts new talent while leveraging technology and generative AI.

In recent years, the World Health Summit in Berlin has become one of the most important meetings for representatives of UN organizations, NGOs, civil society, governments, international financing institutions, and the private sector. I'm always honored to representand meet old friends and new contacts there. What brings us together is improving the health of all people worldwide.

This year, we met under the
motto "Building Trust for a Healthier World". Trust is a topic that is crucial for us as a company in the healthcare industry: the trust of our customers and their patients in our technologies, the trust of our investors in our performance, and last but not least, the trust of entire societies in our values and responsibility.

Trust also grows from honest evaluation of benefits and risks, especially when it comes to new technologies in such a sensitive area as health. I had the opportunity to talk about this in the panel discussion "Artificial Intelligence in Health: From Promise to Practice". As AI is rapidly transforming healthcare, we will not win trust with an isolated discussion about safety. We also need to talk about the opportunities and benefits of AI.

At Siemens Healthineers, we are convinced that digital innovation can help tackle some of the key challenges of the healthcare sector, e.g., by easing the pressure of the workforce shortage. Thus, digital literacy and cybersecurity must become integral parts of any professional training. It is up to us healthcare experts to ensure AI's reliability in medicine, utilize it, and discuss it publicly. We should all be working towards AI becoming a powerful tool in beating cancer and other life-threatening diseases – and in that sense, I would be happy if five years from now a panel topic such as ours yesterday would be an antiquity.
